text: Thank you to @CassiusShuman for his reporting on our most recent report. https://t.co/K5GDLKRlw5

I don't know the specifics of this situation, and without making excuse for the failure here, there typically is not extra staff to perform the significant work needed to implement new programs. The work falls on people stealing time from their day jobs, which already are full. https://t.co/aMnt1y7pP0

Historically, these are low rates of unemployment. RI's unemployment rate was above 5% continuously from mid-2007 through mid-2016, and above 10% from early 2009 through mid-2012.

Latest regional job information through January from @RI_DLT. While unemployment numbers for RI bounce around a bit from month to month, RI's unemployment rate of 4.2% compares favorably to MA (4.8%) and CT (5.3%) and is close to U.S. rate of 4.0%. https://t.co/27Wp0MfwEW
Easing of pandemic restrictions and concerns should lift these job numbers in the short term, but there remains a large deficit (21,100 jobs) yet to be recovered.

While the unemployment rate went down, the number of RI jobs fell by 1,300 in January-- most of the loss (800) was in the Accommodation and Food Services sector. RI has gained 81% of jobs lost during pandemic. https://t.co/GRoUiUxlvF
Very pleased that, after the hearing tonight, the Senate Education Committee approved this resolution, which will now go before the full Senate.

"A constitutional right to education is no silver bullet that will magically fix our schools. However, it might just be the tool we need to commit Rhode Island to transform our schools to better serve our students and the future of our state." https://t.co/OmZAC4V4mY

Many states are looking to make their tax climate more competitive. While RI is continuing to phase out the car tax, and the governor has proposed some modest tax cuts for business, it is worth considering changes to improve our business tax climate. https://t.co/5hNCpjPr0b
RT @TimWhiteRI: Usually the phrase "slot machine catches fire" is a good thing. Not overnight at Twin River: https://t.co/qIFvlzo20Z

Check out RIPEC's latest report--our annual analysis of how RI's taxing and spending compares to U.S. and New England. Policymakers should consider where RI comparatively underinvests in their decisions on where  to deploy our large allocations of federal pandemic relief funding. https://t.co/skasTuUxpI
7 innings does not speed up the game-- it just makes a slow game shorter. A shorter season could perhaps prevent players needing to wearing ski masks in the post-season. https://t.co/sl5v3Mivjs

The tangible property tax has become particularly onerous and burdensome in many communities in RI. Kudos to the Governor for his proposal to allow municipalities to provide exemptions. Business owners need relief from this tax. https://t.co/bvLqOu1log

According to this Stateline article from @pewtrusts, states employ about 5% fewer people in total than they did before the pandemic hit.

If You're a Frontline Worker, States Might Give You a Raise https://t.co/NQhBl5Bc9k via @pewtrusts

Last year more workers qui…

Only CA (7.25%) has a higher state sales tax rate than RI (7%)(3 other states have rates at 7%). But when local sales taxes are included, RI's sales tax ranks 24th. This analysis of rates by @TaxFoundation does not account for the sales tax base, which is relatively narrow in RI. https://t.co/r3tPQ8hWFJ
RT @RIPEC_: We look forward to an engaging discussion on our analysis of this key aspect of municipal finance. https://t.co/CPGVfjaooS
RT @RIPEC_: "How much does the current tax structure discourage business? The Rhode Island Public Expenditure Council’s new report on this,…

Regional job numbers out by @RI_DLT. Mixed news for RI. Unemployment rate for RI is 4.8%, 4.3% for NE. RI is 4th in recovery of jobs since pandemic but close to NE average. RI first in labor force growth since Dec 2020. https://t.co/jPj4SgeDJ5

Providence is a good example of how tax rates have become so out of balance over time: Resident taxpayers enjoy a 40% homestead exemption and pay $14.74 per 1000. Nonresidents pay $24.56. Commercial pays $36.70. Tangible tax rate at $55.80 is four times the resident rate. https://t.co/ibp60iM2kR
RT @AlexaGagosz: New report says Rhode Island’s property tax system is ‘out of balance,’ hindering affordable housing construction, economi…

Check out our latest report on property taxes (there is an executive summary). RIPEC is shining a light on RI's property tax systems, which are out of balance-- causing serious issues for school funding, affordable housing, and economic development. https://t.co/w2GZLWJQYN
The Governor sector-- a large employment sector representing over 13% of all RI jobs has regained only 54% of jobs lost during pandemic

We have now regained 80% of jobs lost during pandemic. Interestingly, Accommodation and Food Services sector had a big gain of 800 jobs in Dec. and has regained 84% lost during pandemic. Education Services has yet to recover any of 3,200 jobs lost during pandemic.

Job numbers from @RI_DLT for December show progress but RI still lagging. Our unemployment rate of 4.8% remains significantly higher than US average of 3.9%. No growth in employed RI residents for December. RI labor force dropped by 1,700. However, RI-based jobs rose by 2,600. https://t.co/CZbH5t9uRl

RIPEC is focused on improving RI's property tax system, specifically through reform of the tangible property tax (we applaud the Governor's effort to address this issue). Businesses pay a disproportionate share of property taxes. Rising home values could make the situation worse.

Thanks to @ProvBusNews for the opportunity to share RIPEC's views on RI's state tax climate. Over the last several years, policymakers have focused on reducing taxes and providing subsidies to certain development projects but have not addressed the heavy tax burden on business. https://t.co/OopXNJMriS
Latest federal income tax data with graphics from @TaxFoundation. Half of taxpayers pay 96.9% of federal income taxes. https://t.co/9ms201hgYG

RIPEC agrees that it's time for tangible tax reform. Tangible taxes are particularly onerous, with significant compliance burdens on small business, and high rates in some communities. Look for more when RIPEC releases our next municipal finance report later this month. https://t.co/JFzHSrYHEG
Great conversation yesterday with Secretary of State @NellieGorbea at our RIPEC membership meeting! https://t.co/gWlKtedhFs

I had the privilege of working with Dr. Alexander-Scott for five years. She has served through some of most trying and difficult circumstances ever faced by a state leader-- essentially an emergency that has never ended. We will miss her dedication and professionalism. https://t.co/TJ1LBpSblU

Recent @TaxFoundation paper focuses on some key reforms that states can pursue to modernize their tax policies in the face of a changing economic landscape. RI fares relatively well, but there are reforms worthy of consideration for the Ocean State. https://t.co/58CP1g0E4r

For the first time in a long time, RI has the fiscal headroom to make some improvements to its business tax climate, which is near the bottom at 40th among states according to the most recent index from @TaxFoundation https://t.co/QwsXdH4WoR
RT @RIPEC_: ICYMI: RIPEC's January newsletter covers the newest edition of the @TaxFoundation State Business Tax Climate Index. See below f…

Thoughtful column by @DanMcGowan on an institution that is critical to the state's future prosperity. RI spends about 30% less per capita on public higher ed than the U.S. average. https://t.co/74ENz1pti2
Eli definitely looks older and more serious. https://t.co/8wPxl9tuns

Check out RIPEC's most recent report. Making our tax systems more competitive for business often comes with a price tag, but state and local governments arguably are in the best position in many years to make reforms, with large inflows of federal funding and strong revenues. https://t.co/xyKkgtU3js
RT @RIPEC_: Wishing a happy and safe New Year to everyone! Thank you to everyone who makes the work RIPEC does possible and to those who fo…

Regional employment numbers are out. RI's unemployment rate of 5.1% is significantly worse than U.S. rate of 4.2% but better than MA (5.4%) and CT (6.0%). There are only five states with higher unemployment rates than CT-- NM, NJ, NY, NV, CA.
https://t.co/27Wp0MfwEW

Employers are responsible for tens of millions of dollars in fraudulent claims. They are also responsible for claims of employees laid off because the economy was partially shut down due to the pandemic. Policymakers should consider some federal funding to recapitalize the fund. https://t.co/JjrucjJ4yr

Makes sense to provide some short-term relief to employers while the economy is still recovering, but it is important to keep in mind that the UI tax is not really a tax-- employers are fully responsible for paying for UI benefits. The question is only when they will pay. https://t.co/0tSVMJJ3Zc
Some excellent journalism by Eli Sherman. Explaining a complicated topic. https://t.co/ac3Zc6HmYa

High earners were relatively insulated from the pandemic, helping to mitigate income tax losses. Sales taxes during the pandemic were strong since online sales were taxed, and services, which were curtailed, are less often included in sales taxes.

There were some one-time factors related to the pandemic at work, but these numbers show a "marked improvement in state fiscal conditions" compared to expectations last year. General fund spending actually grew 4.3% in FY21 over the prior year (RI grew 5%).

State Budget Officers Ass'n just came out with their survey of adopted state budgets. State general fund spending (not federal funds) is projected to grow 9.3% for FY22 over last year--largest percentage increase since 2007 (RI is growing by 10.1%).
https://t.co/l7GoZvxpyV

RI has now recovered 77% of jobs lost from before the pandemic. The thinking was that RI was harder hit than other states because more Travel and Leisure jobs here but that sector has now recovered 78% of jobs lost, and we are still lagging.

RI-based jobs up 2,300 in Nov, and RI labor force--those employed or seeking employment--was up 2,100 to 553,700, closer to the 560,000 range before the pandemic. RI unemployment rate fell to 5.1%, but still significantly worse that U.S. rate of 4.2%.
https://t.co/NjIbVPnqw6
States, flush with cash, are looking to cut taxes. https://t.co/Cy6VMpqZ1k

We also should realize that we are simply fighting fires with this funding for immediate needs. At some point, policymakers need to decide on some investments that could make a difference for the long term.

However, it is important to be transparent about whether spending is temporary or permanent. Permanent spending increases may be warranted but we need to be prepared to pay for them. Some spending items defended as temporary may be hard to reverse.

The Governor and Assembly are right to use ARPA and other federal funds to respond to most pressing needs like homelessness, human services workforce shortages, and support for struggling businesses. https://t.co/rDDsrnoh4p
RT @NeilDSteinberg: Thank you @GovDanMcKee for making these funds available. The grants we make will be to non profit orgs who are boots on…
RT @Provchamber: .@SenatorJackReed and @LW_ProvChamber are discussing the re-nomination of Fed Chair Powell and how he may address inflatio…
RT @RickMetters: Honored to host @SenJackReed @SecYellen and @LW_ProvChamber for the @Provchamber 153rd Annual Meeting. #GPCCEvents #Fideli…

Interesting study from @pewtrusts that looks at revenues and expenses of states including all related entities over FY 2005-19 (pre-pandemic). RI (revenues/expenses at 102%) is in bottom half but not far from median of 102.7%--and better than MA and CT.
https://t.co/53qyYHagxx
RT @RIPEC_: "Yet RIPEC’s @MichaelPDiBiase warns against presuming the current situation shows Rhode Island has escaped its pre-pandemic cyc…

RI still has not regained a quarter of jobs lost from the pandemic. One piece of good news is that our labor force-- those employed or seeking employment is now over 550,000-- getting closer to the 560,000 range before the pandemic.

There is noise from month to month in these numbers. It is likely that the numbers from last month were rosier than actual. We may not be going backward. However, the current jobs picture is not great. RI's unemployment rate is now significantly higher than the U.S. rate. https://t.co/vXFCyzQuDe
One tidbit from this report: filled FTEs are down 833 from peak of 14,256 in March 2020. Thanks to state budget officer Joe Codega for his assistance in understanding these numbers.

The challenge for the Assembly and the Governor is that there is abundant one-time money but most of the spending demands are for continuing program expansions. And the outlook for state revenues for next year is not that bullish.

About half of this surplus is attributable to growth in state revenues/underspending of state expenditures. The remainder is mostly the use of the federal money to pay for expenses that were budgeted to be paid for with state money--the largest is FEMA reimbursement at $217M). https://t.co/UwRnTfeRVv
RT @RIPEC_: We're proud to welcome five new directors to our Board: Robert Brooks of @AdlerPollock, Ross Gittell of @BryantUniv, Matthew Lo…

Certainly a loss. And a position that is hard to fill. Ben has been impressive in this role, particularly in changing payment methodologies to better balance nursing home vs. home care. Something we have talked about for decades but never really advanced. https://t.co/gC9wwZFtu5

Report today by @pewtrusts on labor shortages by state. RI has 1.2 job openings per unemployed person as of Aug 2021. Labor shortages were worse in 32 states, including MA at 1.5 openings per unemployed. CT (at 0.8) has fewer job openings than unemployed. https://t.co/Oe7xDevTyv

Beside massive federal funding flowing to states under the American Rescue Plan Act and the federal infrastructure bill, tax revenues are growing almost every state-- up 17.3% overall in August 2021 as compared with August 2020, according to one source. https://t.co/EDzNuG7TWO

With inflation running high, there not much real growth here (if at all). Federal funds will give relief in the short term, but we need to keep an eye on spending obligations relative to how much state revenues are coming in.

While a windfall in the current year, estimated state revenues are not so great overall. From this report, over 2 years (last year to next) total revenues are up only 7.2%, personal income taxes only up 5.4%. https://t.co/O8kdwBDdDA
I enjoyed the opportunity to join Linda Katz of @EconProgressRI in having this interesting conversation with two former colleagues from state government. https://t.co/z1Hydc1rLk
I do not recommend tuning in on Capitol TV. It is an acquired taste.

Biennial state revenue estimating conference is plodding along today, complicated by taxation of PPP and UI benefits. So far, estimated personal income tax revenues are up over $100M--nearly 7%--in the current fiscal year, but projected to increase only 2.9% next year.

@JGrybowski @RIFoundation Hi Jeff. This could be the OMB Director and added staff. As you know, the OMB Director reports to the Governor and DOA Director. Right now, the Pandemic Recovery Office is a compliance office in DOA.

"State government currently lacks the organizational capacity to effectively plan and manage the very large streams of federal ARPA funding flowing to Rhode Island. Similarly, community-based organizations lack capacity to manage and execute expanded programs."

The recent @RIFoundation report recommended a new office within the Governor's Office to oversee ARPA spending with clear goals, performance metrics, and transparency. https://t.co/ph9Od9MIGB https://t.co/qXbbTJiFJ9

RT @RIPEC_: RIPEC is excited to have @GovDanMcKee, @SenatorRuggerio and @RISpeaker speak on important policy issues in Rhode Island at our…

Big drop in RI's unemployment rate from 5.8% to 5.2% in September. U.S. rate also fell from 5.2% to 4.8%. RI-based jobs increased by 2,000--slightly less than  average over the last 9 months. RI has now regained 75% of jobs lost as a result of pandemic.
https://t.co/h4TAj48tEB

I have had the opportunity to work with Brian Daniels as a colleague in state service and in his role as head of the League. He is a most talented and dedicated individual who will be a valuable addition to Governor’s McKee’s team. https://t.co/BPsWkrL61F
Working on this project, RIPEC had the opportunity to participate in over 60 stakeholder interviews. https://t.co/tA4rnEIZfb

RT @JaredWalczak: On Friday, a federal judge ruled ARPA's Tax Mandate unconstitutionally coercive. That's one of just four arguments states…

Interesting piece @TaxFoundation. RI's UI trust fund has continued to have a positive balance but employers are facing significant tax increases this year to build up the trust fund. Using federal relief funds to replenish the UI trust fund is worth consideration. https://t.co/oKcVaRFbOM
RI looks good in comparison to CT which has an unemployment rate of 7.2%-- ranked 46th among states. CT's labor force is down 1.7% since August 2020, compared to +0.9% for RI, +0.8% for NE.

Regional job numbers from @RI_DLT show RI job growth is middling for New England. RI's unemployment rate of 5.8% is higher than NE at 5.3% (US rate is 5.2%). RI jobs down 5.8% since pre-pandemic, compared to -5.5% for NE, -4.3% for US. https://t.co/8L6xjW64Av

RI has regained 73% of jobs lost during pandemic (including 75% of accommodation & food services jobs). However, that leaves a big gap-- 27,300 jobs-- not yet recovered. The massive federal stimulus has stimulated a lot of economic activity, but we have a long way to go on jobs.

Sluggish August jobs report for RI from @RI_DLT. Unemployment rolls actually slightly up (100) from July. Unemployment rate is up to 5.8% compared to 5.2% for US. While RI-based jobs were up 800, employed RIers were down 1,500, according to this report.
https://t.co/AtWXRUhHxy

However, despite dramatic changes in benefits passed 10 years ago, RI's state pension plan is only 54.5% funded (2019 data). There are only four state plans that have worse funding ratios: IL (38.9%), NJ (39.7%), CT (44.4%), KY (44.6%).

State pension funds are in their best condition since the Great Recession, but uncertainty remains, according to a @pewtrusts report. RI is one of 35 states meeting or exceeding contribution levels needed to stabilize or reduce its pension debt in 2019.
https://t.co/3e3zQi6n9K

@pewtrusts report on slow return of jobs by state. Slowest recovery is mostly in Northeastern states with CT worst at -9.3%. RI is tied for 6th slowest at -6.1%. Report: NE states have more affluent, older residents who may have decided to retire early.
https://t.co/HFbpcq6EXd
Does this mean Scott is taking a break from tweeting? https://t.co/W78jAesUJd

RI fared well in this survey-- in the middle of the pack at 15.4% increase, significantly ahead of most Northeast states. RI was actually slightly positive even when government transfers were excluded.

Interesting survey from @pewtrusts on personal income growth over last year. For 2021/Q1, nearly all states recorded double-digit growth in personal income compared with the same period a year earlier, driven largely by the spike in government assistance.
https://t.co/1l7gOHenab

Very sad news of Carole’s passing. I had the privilege to work closely with Carole for nearly five years. She brought a wealth of government experience and dedication to a very challenging job. She will be missed. https://t.co/L6AQplq5Af
Northeast, including RI, have relatively property taxes, but there are places with much higher property taxes than the Ocean State. https://t.co/dKitBQG4rH

RT @RIPEC_: RIPEC's September newsletter is out now.

RT @NeilDSteinberg: Great to partner with @RIPEC_  and @EconProgressRI on this very important initiative with a great committee and much pu…

I had the privilege of working closely with both Peter Keenan and Dottie Pascale. Peter was a consummate finance professional as controller. Dottie, who has served as the state's top auditor, is a very experienced leader and highly qualified to fill this role.

The state controller is a little known, but very important, position in state government. The controller decides on the accounting treatment of all revenues and expenditures, subject only to the Auditor General's final determination. https://t.co/sAeP3bwHd9

Accounting for the FEMA reimbursement complicates the surplus calculation for last year. It looks like normal expenditures are about $65M under appropriations. Total positive swing (revenues and expenditures) from this FY21 closing statement is about $275M.

Big news here is that revenues for last fiscal year (ending 6/30/21) are over $200M higher than estimated in May. This will likely increase the base and lead to higher estimates in November for the current year. https://t.co/6eEqwD6861
Awesome photo. https://t.co/37Z0mUeRtf
RI's unemployment rate at 5.8% is ranked 34th worst in US-- higher than NE average of 5.2% and US average of 5.4%-- and much higher than MA unemployment rate of 4.9%.
RI jobs grew 7.1% from July of last year--slightly better than NE average of 6.9%. RI jobs still down 5.6% since pre-pandemic-- compared to down 5.5% for NE and 4.5% for U.S.
Regional job numbers out from @RI_DLT. RI is growing jobs at a decent clip but unemployment in RI remains stubbornly high. https://t.co/8L6xjWnFZ5
Hard not to like BobbyD and he seems to be improving at the plate, but the statistical link to JBJ is no compliment. https://t.co/hGYooxAqiW

Interested in @PaulDion5 take.

Very interesting stuff. Keep in mind taxable grocery sales are a small subset of overall grocery sales, but percentage increase is probably close to total sales. Groceries up less than restaurants down, but probably reflects bigger base for groceries. https://t.co/hCsoExVuIP
Redistricting process will be interesting to watch. https://t.co/9sAqaMpLaf

Very interesting piece by the dynamic duo @wpri12. It is little difficult to understand growth in communities that have had little in the way of new housing units to my knowledge. Could it be more mailing addresses in the same household? Renesting? https://t.co/hvjEDKbThW
We have now recovered 74% of jobs lost during the pandemic.

RI's unemployment rate fell from 5.9% in June to 5.8%. But U.S. rate fell from 5.9% to 5.4%. While these numbers bounce around on a month-to-month basis, it looks like RI economy is adding jobs at a fast clip, but unemployed are still slow to take them.

RI job numbers for July are out. Big jump in RI-based jobs--up 7200 in July--highest monthly gain since Aug 2020. However number of unemployed RI residents fell only 1100 since June. 
https://t.co/AtWXRUhHxy

As very mediocre golfer, Dan's column spoke to me this morning. https://t.co/7GIGuTRWvm

Informative piece by Eli Sherman. In my lifetime, I have seen the geographical power center of the Assembly move from urban areas (Providence/Pawtucket) toward the large suburban cities (Warwick/Cranston). While the population changes are not large, we may see a swing back. https://t.co/E7AZMsZZY9

I had the privilege to work closely with Jonathan Womer for five years. Tremendous experience and knowledge of government budgeting combined with strong values and character. A true professional. A loss for state government. https://t.co/499Ch8U2vD

Hard to see a pattern here. Strong growth in urban communities. Growth in CF is noteworthy but may be due in part to better counting. Cumb/Lincoln had strong growth. Warw, EP noteworthy in virtually no growth. Decline in Narr may be second homes replacing permanent residents. https://t.co/E9b6ERfavC

Regional job numbers published for June. RI at 5.9% is same as U.S. but slightly worse than NE (5.3%). Big change is that MA rate is now down to 4.9% after previously higher than RI. CT at 7.9% is remarkably ranked 50th in US.
https://t.co/8L6xjWnFZ5
RT @IanDon: This Statehouse portrait of Gov. Notte is …. Vivid https://t.co/jthrPc9tPY

Interesting report by @TaxFoundation on gas taxes. A very wide range among states. RI is 19th highest at 35 cents per gallon. While RI's tax is indexed to inflation every two years, revenues have narrowed because of fuel economy and electric vehicles. https://t.co/mUGS66Ut51

Pew reports that 20 states, including RI, had tax revenues that fully recovered to pre-pandemic levels by end of 2020. RI was up 2.4%.  https://t.co/bv6ZOG96wV

RI labor force-- those working or actively looking for work-- dropped 1,900 in April, and is down 22,400 since pre-pandemic. This is a national trend, but is concerning for RI-- we have only 539,600 RI residents in the labor force.

Employed RI residents up 2,400 since March-- a big jump-- but RI-based jobs increased by only 400. Accommodation and Food Service sector up 500 in April but still has regained only 67% of pre-pandemic jobs. Construction also up 500, fully recovered lost jobs.

Positive RI jobs report for April. Unemployment rate down to 6.3% from 7.0% in March. RI's rate is now close to U.S. rate of 6.1%. Unemployed RIers down 4,300 from March-- a big drop of over 11% in one month. https://t.co/AtWXRUhHxy

71.1% of RI charter school students come from low income families--constituting 9.9% of all poverty level students in RI. Providence, with 84.8% low income students, enrolls 16.2% of RI public school students and receives 26.4% of state ed aid.

With all due respect, this data is inaccurate and misleading. Charter schools made up 6.7% of public school students and receive 9.4% of state ed aid in FY19. Charters get a higher proportion because the state aid formula weights for student poverty level. https://t.co/Xgj6ndkCn3

The real play for this FY 22 budget will be hundreds of millions of dollars in new federal money that will be rolled into this budget before it is enacted and thereafter. RI needs to be strategic and maximize this once-in-a-generation opportunity.

Partial tax hit on PPP loans is also questionable, since it departs from federal policy and the position of most states. While characterized as offsetting lost revenues, these loans were grants and resulting taxes were essentially found money for RI.

Continued phase out of the car tax is questionable-- we never had a source for this tax cut and are essentially using one-time federal money to make this cut-- which may not even be legally permitted under the American Rescue Act passed this week.
McKee deserves praise for avoiding broad-based tax increases, tackling the unsustainable situation at Eleanor Slater Hospital, trying to fix the state's weak housing policy.
It will be critical to avoid the temptation to use abundant federal funding to pay for more recurring state spending-- which could make the structural deficit even more unmanageable.

Gov. McKee's FY 22 budget is relatively conservative--it still relies on federal funds to plug the state's budget gap, but does not appear to materially worsen the structural deficit, pegged at $374M for FY23.
Accommodation & Food Services Sector added 1,700 jobs in January, regaining about 2/3 of jobs lost from November "pause," but Sector is still down 12,000 jobs since before the pandemic.
